source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: The other properties of the products are shown in Table 10. The data are consistent with standard Zircaloy-2 cladding tube for BWRs.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: A new quenching machine and method where the tube shell can be α + β through-wall quenched at a rapid cooling rate (> 50 K/s from 1173 to 1073 K) has been developed.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: High nodular corrosion-resistant tube shells quenched at both hollow billet and tube shell stages, have less deformability, especially in the circumferential compression.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: Crack sensitivity in cold pilgering can be correlated to a combination of the reduction in area and Q value. Higher reduction (> 80%) pilgerings with higher Q values (> 2) are proved possible.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: Crack sensitivity in cold pilgering can be correlated to a combination of the reduction in area and Q value. Higher reduction (> 80%) pilgerings with higher Q values (> 2) are proved possible.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: The new two-step reduction process allows fabrication of tubing with a low annealing parameter (Σ A_i = 2.8 × 10^{-20}

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: The tube shells and final tubing using the new fabrication process showed high nodular corrosion resistance and had no nodules in the 773 K corrosion tests.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: In the hydrogen uptake test for the final products, we could not see the difference between the developed tubing and the conventional tubing.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: The temperature was 893 to 923 K.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: the final products of the new process were evaluated in the 673 K, 72 h autoclave test. Consequently, there were no differences between the product of the new process and one of the conventional process.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: The frequency is 2 kHz.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: The tube shell stayed in the coil for 25 s.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: The uniform corrosion resistance of Zircaloy-4 sheets produced under various hot-rolling and annealing conditions was investigated.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: The uniform corrosion resistance in static steam at $\bar { \bf 6 } 7 3 { \bf \ K }$ improved with an increasing cumulative annealing parameter $( \Sigma A )$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: the annealing temperature after hot-rolling influenced the uniform corrosion more significantly than the intermediate annealing and the final annealing temperatures.
process_step: annealing after hot-rolling; intermediate annealing; final annealing

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: The percentage of small precipitates below $1 0 0 \ \mathrm { n m }$ in size was important in determining corrosion resistance and had a good correlation with the annealing parameter; that is, if the percentage was lower than $30 \%$ , the corrosion resistance was satisfactory.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: the frequency of precipitates under $1 0 0 \ \mathrm { n m }$ in size decreased sharply with increasing annealing temperature after hot-rolling.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: the iron/chromium $\scriptstyle ( F e / C r )$ ratio for the zirconium-chromiumiron intermetallic precipitate was approximately 1 compared to approximately 2 in the Zircaloy matrix.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: the iron/chromium $\scriptstyle ( F e / C r )$ ratio for the zirconium-chromiumiron intermetallic precipitate was approximately 1 compared to approximately 2 in the Zircaloy matrix.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: It was observed that a stress-relieved microstructure of the Zircaloy-4 just beneath the growing front of the oxide was transformed into a recrystallized microstructure. This was especially clear in a high $\pmb { \Sigma A }$ material compared to a low $\Sigma \bar { A }$ material.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: This seems to be one of the reasons that a higher $\pmb { \Sigma A }$ Zircaloy-4 is more corrosion resistant under uniform corrosion conditions.
